skill.name: building-plugins
skill.description: Expert at creating and managing Claude Code plugins that bundle agents, skills, commands, and hooks into cohesive packages. Auto-invokes when the user wants to create, structure, validate, or publish a complete plugin, or needs help with plugin architecture and best practices. Also auto-invokes proactively when Claude is about to create plugin directory structures, write plugin.json manifests, or implement tasks that involve bundling components into a plugin package.

content.value_statement: Create plugins that bundle agents, skills, commands, and hooks into distributable packages. Includes validation tools, templates, and best practices for secure plugin development.

best_practices: Use minimal allowed-tools lists and require user confirmation for destructive operations
Store credentials in environment variables and add secrets files to .gitignore
Validate all script inputs and avoid eval() or dynamic code execution
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys or credentials in plugin.json or source files
Skipping security validation hooks for Bash tool usage
Publishing plugins without reviewing component permissions

faq.question: What is the difference between a skill and a plugin?
faq.answer: A skill is a single auto-invoked capability. A plugin bundles multiple related skills, commands, agents, and hooks into one distributable package.

faq.question: Can I include secrets in my plugin?
faq.answer: Never hardcode secrets. Use environment variables like ${API_KEY} and document required configuration for users to set up.

faq.question: How do I validate my plugin before publishing?
faq.answer: Run the validate-plugin.py script to check structure, schema compliance, and security patterns. Address any warnings before distribution.

faq.question: What permissions should my plugin request?
faq.answer: Use the minimum required tools. Only request dangerous tools like Bash or Write when necessary and require user confirmation.

faq.question: How do I version my plugin?
faq.answer: Follow semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Bump MAJOR for breaking changes, MINOR for new features, PATCH for fixes.

faq.question: Can I use hooks for security?
faq.answer: Yes. PreToolUse hooks can validate dangerous commands before execution. See the validate-bash.sh hook template for examples.
